lexUnit.name: cloak.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: an overgarment that hangs loosely from the shoulders over the arms to the knees or ankles.

sentence.text: A cloak of velvet , a mask of silk , the dim candlelight , suddenly these things seemed too flimsy for disguise , and the little package felt as large and heavy as a case lined with lead .
Aunt Margaret sat on a bank of primroses , naked but for a cloak of brilliant green loosely slung around her shoulders .
A little later , the door opened as he was groaning and moving around in his bed , and a nurse with a dark blue cloak over her uniform came in , closing the door behind her .
Where shall ye now get as much money as ye owe ? " , and when she was given forty pence she bought herself a furred cloak with it rather than paying off any of her debts .

As I said she wore a mask , and a rich black cloak with white lambswool trimmings .
I tied the horse to graze and , burying myself in my cloak out of the wind , I slept , almost as peacefully as any mercenary , armed with sword and pike .

The little man pulled his cloak tighter about his shoulders .
He put on his cloak and padded over to the door .

She put on her cloak and went downstairs .
He took the dirty threadbare cloak and , finding the cleanest spot in the hall , lay down and fell asleep .
Ruth took off the cloak , shivering -- though , if anything , the sun seemed to reach her more warmly now .
I took off my cloak and immediately began to thread the fabric through the hole .
He shaved , changed his doublet , put on his sword belt and took his heaviest cloak from its hook outside the buttery .

Wearing a black , gold-embroidered silk cloak over a finely woven shamma , he came across the room to greet us , shook hands and with a smile and a gesture invited us to be seated .
He wore a heavy cloak of dark cloth that came down to his ankles .

He had a lantern lit by the time she had dressed , wrapping herself last of all in the big , hooded cloak she had brought for Birsay .
